title: 108_hr4607
content: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Organic Act of 2004 establishes the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration within the Department of Commerce. SEC. 103. DEFINITIONS. The terms "NOAA" and "Administration" refer to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Commerce. The terms "Under Secretary" or "Administrator" refer to the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere and Administrator of NOAA. The terms "Assistant Secretary" or "Deputy Administrator" refer to the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere and Deputy Administrator of NOAA. (a) Under Secretary.--There shall be an Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere and Administrator of NOAA appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Under Secretary will be the head of NOAA with authority, direction, and control. All authority vested in NOAA can be exercised by the Under Secretary. The Under Secretary may delegate duties to designated persons or organizations within NOAA. (b) Within NOAA, there is an Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Assistant Secretary performs functions as prescribed by the Under Secretary and acts in their absence or vacancy. Additionally, there is a Deputy Under Secretary appointed by the Secretary to perform the Assistant Secretary's functions when necessary. The Secretary may act as the Assistant Secretary during their disability or vacancy. The Under Secretary can establish positions within NOAA to carry out assigned functions. SEC. 105. PURPOSES AND AUTHORITIES. NOAA's purposes include observing, assessing, and predicting changes in ecosystems, managing and protecting marine resources, collecting and providing scientific data for sound decision-making, and ensuring public safety. The Under Secretary of NOAA has authorities to make safety decisions, protect lives and property, expand economic opportunities, and collaborate with various entities including Federal agencies, State and local governments, international organizations, and commercial organizations. The Under Secretary of NOAA has the authority to promulgate rules and regulations, enter into contracts, leases, grants, and agreements necessary for NOAA's purposes with various entities without regard to certain sections of Title 31. Authority for NOAA to accept gifts, bequests, and utilize services, money, securities, or property from any source without restrictions, and to use the services, equipment, personnel, and facilities of various entities with or without reimbursement. Authority for NOAA to disseminate information, conduct education and outreach, acquire, lease, invest, sell, and dispose of property, and construct and maintain real or personal property. The authority granted includes purchasing vehicles, hiring experts, and consultants, without time limitations, at specified daily rates. The authority granted includes purchasing vehicles, hiring experts, and consultants at specified daily rates, as well as covering travel expenses, telephone services, and official reception expenditures. Protection Against Misuse of Name, Initials, and Seal: No person may use NOAA's name, initials, or seal without written permission, in a way that implies approval or endorsement by NOAA. The Attorney General can initiate civil proceedings in a US district court to enjoin acts or practices that violate certain conduct prohibitions. The court can issue restraining orders or take action to prevent harm to the United States or individuals. SEC. 106. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS, REPEALS AND TRANSITION. The Reorganization Plan No. 4 of 1970 is repealed. References to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in any law or document prior to this Act will now apply to the new administration established by this Act. References to specific positions within NOAA will also be updated accordingly. Repeal of subsections 407(a) and 407(b) of Public Law 99-659 (15 U.S.C. 1503b and 1507c) and amendments to Title 5 of the United States Code regarding the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere and Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The text chunk discusses the amendment to the position of Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere and Deputy Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The first appointments to these positions will be made by the President alone. SEC. 107 of the Act states that all rules, regulations, contracts, and actions assigned to the Secretary of Commerce or NOAA officials will remain in effect until modified or rescinded. SEC. 108 clarifies that the Act does not affect other laws or agencies. TITLE II--NOAA ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON OCEANS AND ATMOSPHERE - SEC. 201. AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to sections 2 through 8 of the National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere Act of 1977. This includes changes to the appointment and qualifications of Committee members by the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere. The Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere appoints members to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Science Advisory Board to serve on the Committee. The term of office for Committee members is 3 years, with staggered initial terms for continuity. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, with a limit of serving for two terms. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Science Advisory Board members can serve for a maximum of two consecutive three-year terms. The Committee advises the Under Secretary on NOAA programs. Sections 4 and 6 are deleted and renumbered accordingly. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Science Advisory Board members can serve for a maximum of two consecutive three-year terms. Sections 4 and 6 are deleted and renumbered accordingly. The term "National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere" is replaced with "NOAA Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere" in relevant sections.
